review-content: I know I'm going against the grain here guys, but you'll have to forgive me.  It's not that Sol Café has done anything to offend me, but my type of soul doesn't exactly jive with theirs.  As hard as I try, I have such a difficulty getting down with coffee shops that exude hipster-ness.  I have come to accept the fact that all good coffee shops are pretty much run by hipsters (I give credit where credit is due), but when the coffee shop is throwing up hipster vibes, I'm just not catching what they're throwing.  I'm sorry, but when I have to read about Karl Marx in the toilet stall (assumed because some hipster wrote it), I draw the line...I've learned plenty about Karl Marx in my day  so forgive me if I don't want to think about it and other political views in the bathroom.  That was a tangent, I know, but I'll get off my soapbox now.Let me just blurt out the other couple things I wasn't so fond of before I get to the positive aspects of Sol Café.  Personally, I find most of the seating here uncomfortable so that doesn't make for the most pleasant experience.  Secondly, on the two occasions I've gone I've received mixed service.  The first time I was somewhat dismissed by staff whereas the second time they couldn't have been nicer.  And lastly, the coffee and lattes are not my favorite - I felt as if the flavor was very bland, but then again that could have been due to the fact that I got an iced latte.  I will give them the benefit of the doubt.  The tea combinations they offer do look interesting and I would be open to trying that the next time I come here.  Onto the good parts of Sol Café!  Weirdly enough, my favorite aspect is the fact that they offer free parking behind the cafe itself.  All of you Chicagoans should know what a b**** and a half it is to find free parking in the city so this is a very welcome luxury.  Call me weird, but I get excited about free parking.  As if that's not enough, though, you can find Glazed N' Infused Donuts here.  It's a limited selection, but hey its a one-stop shop...can you really complain about that?  At first I was a bit disappointed that they didn't make their own baked goods, but then again at least Sol Café does offer some sweet treats...other cafes can't always say the same thing.  Lastly, I love the fact that they have a printer hooked up to the cafe so that if you're doing work there (like I've found myself doing a few times now) you have access to a printer instead of having to go back to your office for this.  The printer costs about 20 cents I believe, but you're paying for convenience.  Just be conscientious of when you go here because there tends to be a lot of characters hanging around the area; it is somewhat secluded from other businesses which can be a little nerve-wracking, at least for me, but maybe not for you.

review-content: I started going to Sol a couple of months after it first opened, and have been so pleased to have it in the neighborhood. It's a great place to meet a friend for coffee, to bring a book or computer and hang out for awhile, and I've even had staff meeting with my co-workers here as well. I also appreciate the way they seem very intentional about becoming part of the neighborhood, and specifically the Howard area - I remember being afraid that I would only ever see other clientele like myself (young, white 20-somethings), but have been pleased to see a diversity in age and culture that seems to embody the feel of Rogers Park.
